questions.question_text: What is the role of vSmart in a Cisco SD-WAN environment?

choices.D: to perform initial authentication of devices
choices.A: to establish secure control plane connections
choices.B: to monitor, configure, and maintain SD-WAN devices
choices.C: to provide secure data plane connectivity over WAN links

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A) is vSmart using OMP to communicate with vEdge routers. (CORRECT)
B) is vManage.
C) is VPNs.
D) is vBond.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A. To establish secure control plane connections

vSmart controllers play a crucial role in orchestrating and managing the control plane operations in an SD-WAN architecture. They are responsible for establishing and maintaining secure control plane connections among different SD-WAN devices (such as edge routers or vEdge devices).

These controllers help in enforcing policies, distributing routing information, facilitating secure communication between SD-WAN components, and ensuring that the SD-WAN fabric operates based on defined business policies and requirements. They play a key role in controlling the behavior and forwarding decisions of SD-WAN devices by providing centralized intelligence for the control plane of the network.
i think it's D , check pag 634 of the Cert GUID
answer is A ... but question is poorly worded.

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct answer here.

comments.content: maybe right, but the answer c is data plane connection, so maybe that why the answer c is wrong because we know that vsmart is in control plane

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I think C is correct to, vSmart authenticates devices connected to the SD-WAN network
I think C is correct to, vSmart authenticates devices connected to the SD-WAN network

vSmart controller distributes security information between vEdge routers to facilitate data plane IPSEC tunnel creation. vSmart uses OMP to distribute routing information, security keys and policy configuration through DTLS tunnels to the vEdge routers.

Selected Answer: C
Option A is incorrect.
The authentication type is cleartext; 'text' keyword is being used.
We can use md5 authentication by using 'authentication md5' command.

Option B is incorrect, and irrelevant to the context of our question.
We need to use 'show ip route' command to display R2's routing table and confirm.

Option C is correct.
We will track the reachability to IP address '10.10.1.1' in its routing table and if it's not reachable by R1, R1's priority will decrement by 20. This will set R1's priority to '90' making it less than R2's default priority (100,) and R2 becomes the active router.

Option D is incorrect
If R1 reboots, R2 becomes the primary virtual router until R1 comes back. (Tested in PT)

comments.content:
R1 is primary as long as 10.10.1.1/32 is reachable in the routing table, if this fails, the priority decremets to 90.

........

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct.
tricky question

b is completely wrong, there is nothing in the question that can be used to identify if b is correct or wrong.
D is correct until you remember that preemption is default in VRRP :D

C seems to be wrong at first, then you look at the track again to see that it's tracking the IP route entry in the routing table not pinging the ip

comments.content: R1's prio is 110. When the tracked object fails, the prio is decremented by 20, lowering it below R2's default prio, 100. But C says when the route is installed (meaning reachable), so R1's prio remains 110, and master. Still C, nevertheless.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
answer makes sense.
A- Wrong, its cleartext
B- Wrong, not enough information to infer this
C- Correct, if there is reachability to the network 10.10.1.1/32, R1's priority is default 100, which is equal to R2's priority of default 100, so what is the next tie breaker? the higher IP address, R1 wins, and with VRRP having preempt enabled by default, R1 becomes the Master.
D- Wrong

Selected Answer: C
C is the correct answer

Selected Answer: C
R1 tracks a /32 network and remove vrrp priority if the /32 goes away.

It is NOT D, Why ? Because preemption is enabled by default. Which means that if R1 reboots -> R2 will become primary and when R1 reboot is finished will take the role again because of the default preemption ! -> C seems right.

Selected Answer: C
cisco_R3(config-subif)#do s runn interface Ethernet0/0.40
!
interface Ethernet0/0.40
 encapsulation dot1Q 40
 ip address 172.16.13.2 255.255.255.0
 vrrp 10 ip 172.16.13.254
 vrrp 10 track 4 decrement 20
end

cisco_R3(config-subif)#do s track 4
Track 4
 IP route 5.5.5.55 255.255.255.255 reachability
 Reachability is Down (no ip route)
 1 change, last change 00:04:13
 First-hop interface is unknown
 Tracked by:
 VRRP Ethernet0/0.40 10

cisco_R3(config-subif)#do s vrrp
Ethernet0/0.40 - Group 10
 State is Master
 Virtual IP address is 172.16.13.254
 Virtual MAC address is 0000.5e00.010a
 Advertisement interval is 1.000 sec
 Preemption enabled <<<<<<<<<< by default, so it'll become MASTER after high priority
 Priority is 80
 Track object 4 state Down decrement 20
 Master Router is 172.16.13.2 (local), priority is 80
 Master Advertisement interval is 1.000 sec
 Master Down interval is 3.609 sec

cisco_R3(config-subif)#

cisco_R3(config-subif)#

cisco_R3(config-subif)#

cisco_R3(config-subif)#
cisco_R3(config-subif)#do s track 4

discussion.content:
tricky question, I hate it ...
D. is true anyway,
C. is unclear, let's say what happens if this route flaps? after that R2 will be master anyway cos no feature PREEMPTION is configured on R1... right?

Selected Answer: C
i think that is close answer

comments.content: Look close the D answer: . If R1 reboots, R2 becomes the primary virtual router until R2 reboots. (R2 reboots !)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I believe D is correct because preemption is enabled in VRRP by default.
The answer C says " if 10.10.1.1/32 is in its routing table." if this route is statically configured it will still be there disregarding its reachability.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct because of the tracking feature. Exhibit speaks nothing about availability of routes, so we can not tell which routes are available or not available.

Selected Answer: C
Provides answer is correct. R1 is primary if 10.10.1.1/32 is in its routing table. -> because of track 20 command

A believe it is C. By ''sh run int fa0/0'' command we are not able to tell if route is in routing table or not. On router 1 is configured IP SLA which is tracking reachability to 10.10.1.1 - so if this route is unavailable, routers 1 priority decrements and it becomes Secondary, but if the route is reachable it will stay Primary because of its 110 priority.

comments.content:
Not D; VRRP has preempt on by default, so R1 will take back over as primary when it can.

Answer is C

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Answer: B

comments.content: there was no output regarding routing table, so you can't say if yes or no

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I believe B is true.

choices.B: There is no route to 10.10.1.1/32 in R2's routing table.
choices.D: If R1 reboots, R2 becomes the primary virtual router until R2 reboots.
choices.A: Communication between VRRP members is encrypted using MD5.
choices.C: R1 is primary if 10.10.1.1/32 is in its routing table.
